entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 15 at 1:58PM CDT until March 15 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF SOUTHEAST NORTH DAKOTA THIS AFTERNOON INTO EARLY EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are expected over much of southeast North Dakota, especially west of the Red River valley. In this area lowest relative humidity values of 20 to 25 percent is expected by mid to late afternoon along with west wind gusts 30 to 40 mph. Fuels are dry and with wind gusts and low humidity values any fire that may start has the potential to grow and spread quickly.
* AFFECTED AREA...In North Dakota, Barnes, Cass, Ransom, Sargent and Richland.
* WIND...West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph.
* HUMIDITY...as low as 20 percent
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Barnes; Cass; Ransom; Sargent; Richland

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 1:58PM EDT until March 17 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting New London and Washington Counties.
For the Pawcatuck River...including Westerly...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Pawcatuck River at Westerly.
* WHEN...Until late Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding occurs along the Pawcatuck River. Along Route 3 in Hopkinton, floodwaters encroach on lowest lying homes in French Village.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:00 PM EDT Friday the stage was 7.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 7.0 feet late tonight. It will then fall to 6.8 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will rise to 6.9 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall to 6.8 feet early Sunday morning. It will rise to flood stage this afternoon. It will then fall again but remain above flood stage. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: New London, CT; Washington, RI

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE SUNDAY MORNING

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 6 and 12 inches, except locally around 18 inches on higher peaks. Lesser amounts near Des Moines and Capulin.
* WHERE...Sangre de Cristo Mountains, and Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Tire traction will be reduced. Extend the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. This includes along portions of I-25.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Northeast wind gusts up to 35 mph will create areas of blowing and drifting snow from near Raton Pass east through Capulin and Des Moines until mid afternoon Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Central Highlands, Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass, Upper Rio Grande Valley, and Southwest Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on snow packed or icy road conditions. This includes portions of I-40. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday evening commute. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Areas of blowing snow may reduce visibility to near one quarter mile at times creating hazardous driving conditions. Wind speeds will weaken late Friday evening.

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Sandia and Manzano Mountains including Edgewood, Chuska Mountains, West Central Mountains, and Jemez Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MDT Saturday.

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Middle Rio Grande Valley including the Albuquerque Metro Area, and West Central Highlands.
* WHEN...Until midnight MDT tonight.
* IMPACTS...Damaging winds may blow down trees and power lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel will be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued March 15 at 12:05PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control in Columbia SC has issued a Code Orange Fine Particulates Action Day for the Upstate region of South Carolina, until midnight EDT tonight.
An Air Quality Alert means that the fine particulate concentrations within the specified areas may approach or exceed unhealthy standards for individuals sensitive to particulate pollution.
DHEC recommends that individuals with respiratory health issues limit time spend outdoors and/or move all activities indoors to avoid the smoke or fine particulates. Keep windows and doors closed. Run an air conditioner if you have one but keep the fresh-air intake closed and the filter clean to prevent outdoor smoke and fine particulates from getting inside.
For more information about fine particulates, please visit: https://fire.airnow.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cherokee; Anderson; Abbeville; Laurens; Union; Greenwood; Oconee Mountains; Pickens Mountains; Greenville Mountains; Greater Oconee; Greater Pickens; Central Greenville; Southern Greenville; Northern Spartanburg; Southern Spartanburg

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.

entry.title: High Surf Warning issued March 15 at 3:28AM HST until March 15 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR NORTH AND WEST FACING SHORES OF NIIHAU KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI AND NORTH FACING SHORES OF MAUI... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR WEST FACING SHORES OF THE BIG ISLAND...
.A large northwest (320 degrees) swell will peak this morning, producing warning level surf along the exposed north- and west- facing shores. The swell will gradually decline this afternoon through the weekend.
* WHAT...Surf of 25 to 35 feet along north-facing shores, and up to 24 feet along west-facing shores.
* WHERE...North and west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and north facing shores of Maui.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST this evening.
* IMPACTS...High. Expect very strong breaking waves and powerful currents. Waves breaking in channel entrances may make navigating the channels dangerous.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Wayne and Long Counties.
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Toombs, Montgomery and Jeff Davis Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Toombs, Wayne, Appling and Tattnall Counties.
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting Wayne, Glynn and McIntosh Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 900 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Bankfull conditions occur along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Some flooding begins in low lying areas around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage in south Montgomery County. The water will approach portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 13.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding occurs in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water reaches the top of the public boat ramp by the bridge. Flood waters expand in low lying areas in south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will begin to cover portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 18.0 feet, Minor flooding expands further into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will completely cover Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge and begin to flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 4 to 6 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane... Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 19.0 feet, Minor flooding expands upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters near 3 feet deep cover Towns Bluff Lane and flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery County with the water 5 to 7 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The water reaches the top of boat ramps and parking lots will begin to flood in Towns Bluff Park and along the end of Uvalda Landing Road in Jeff Davis County. At 20.0 feet, Moderate flooding begins. Significant flooding occurs upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will be near 4 feet deep on Towns Bluff Lane and flood the concrete slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery county with the water 6 to 8 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The parking lot at Towns Bluff Park and portions of Uvalda Landing Road will be flooded in Jeff Davis County. At 21.0 feet, Significant flooding continues upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will be near 5 feet deep on Towns Bluff Lane and flood the concrete slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery County with the water 7 to 9 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The parking lot at Towns Bluff Park and a pavilion and picnic area off Uvalda Landing Road will be flooded in Jeff Davis County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM EDT Friday the stage was 17.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 19.2 feet early Monday morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jeff Davis, GA; Montgomery, GA; Toombs, GA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 8:58AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Wayne and Long Counties.
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Toombs, Montgomery and Jeff Davis Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Toombs, Wayne, Appling and Tattnall Counties.
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting Wayne, Glynn and McIntosh Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 900 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Everett City.
* WHEN...From this evening until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Agricultural and timber lands near the river are flooded. At 13.0 feet, Water begins to encroach upon Altamaha Regional Park in Glynn County. This includes Altamaha Park Road, Betty Lott Lane and Bee Tree Island Road. In McIntosh County, Barrington Park at the end of Harper Lake Road begins to flood. Blue Reach Road also begins to flood near the Long County line. At 14.0 feet, Portions of Altamaha Regional Park become inundated, including the park campground, boat ramps and parking lots. Bee Tree Island Road is flooded and closed. The end of Betty Lott Lane is flooded and homes become cut off. At 15.0 feet, In Glynn County, the majority of Altamaha Regional Park becomes inundated, including water flowing across sections of Altamaha Park Road and Pennick Road. The Altamaha Regional Park is subject to closure at this level. Homes in the vicinity of the park are cut off by flood waters at this level, but elevated structures are not flooded. In McIntosh County, much of Barrington Park is underwater. Plum Orchard Road begins to flood. At 16.5 feet, In McIntosh County, water will approach a few elevated homes on Barrington Ferry Road, possibly restricting access.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 12.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening and continue rising to 14.5 feet Wednesday morning. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 15 at 3:36AM AKDT until March 15 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...MORE SNOW FOR THE KLONDIKE HIGHWAY...
.A front moving northward today will bring more snow to the Klondike Highway. All areas from Skagway to the summit are expected to start out as snow this morning, but Skagway is expected to change to rain sometime in the afternoon. Snow levels are expected to rise rapidly this afternoon and evening eventually reaching 2500 feet by late evening before precipitation starts to diminish.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway above 1500 feet
* WHEN...From 10 AM this morning to 10 PM AKDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Lower snow totals of around 1 to 3 inches expected at Skagway and Dyea. Snow is expected to be rather wet and heavy especially near sea level.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 15 at 3:36AM CDT until March 15 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF SOUTHWEST AND SOUTH CENTRAL NORTH DAKOTA THIS AFTERNOON INTO EARLY THIS EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are expected across much of southwest and south central North Dakota this afternoon into early this evening. Afternoon relative humidity values will drop as low as 15 percent, while sustained southwesterly to westerly winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 45 mph are expected. Winds will then start to turn northwest towards evening as a cold front moves through the area. Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly in dry fuels and become difficult to control or suppress.
The National Weather Service in Bismarck has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from 1 PM CDT /noon MDT/ this afternoon to 8 PM CDT /7 PM MDT/ this evening.
* WINDS...Southwesterly to westerly at 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. Winds may start to shift northwest towards evening.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* AFFECTED AREA...Much of southwest and south central North Dakota.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control or suppress.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Golden Valley; Billings; Stark; Morton; Burleigh; Kidder; Stutsman; Slope; Hettinger; Grant; Bowman; Adams; Sioux; Emmons; Logan; La Moure; McIntosh; Dickey

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 14 at 3:14PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Northeast winds of 15 to 30 mph are expected to develop along the West Coast of Alaska Friday night and continue into Sunday. Wind chills of 30 to 50 below area expected Friday night through Sunday caused by these winds.
A dramatic shift in the weather is expected by Tuesday or Wednesday next week. A series of storms approaching the West Coast of Alaska from the southwest will bring strong winds, temperatures above freezing, and the possibility of heavy snow and blizzard conditions, and possibly even areas of rain.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 14 at 3:08AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
After a period of cold wind chills and dominant arctic air lasting through this upcoming weekend, a significant shift in the regional weather pattern will begin early Tuesday of next week as moist Pacific flow returns, bringing warming south winds and the potential for periods of storminess. This is a classic late winter/early spring time pattern with a myriad of weather impacts including temps above freezing, strong south winds, locally heavy snow, mixed precipitation, and blowing snow. Right now, the warmup looks highly probable, with timing and impacts of possible storms still much more uncertain.
Residents are encouraged to stay up to date with the latest forecast at www.weather.gov/fairbanks and be prepared for an upcoming weather pattern shift.

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued March 13 at 4:41PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVWBOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM WEDNESDAY UNTIL 5 PM FRIDAY...
*WHAT... Avalanche conditions are very dangerous. The Avalanche Danger is HIGH (Level 4 of 5)
*WHERE... Medicine Bow Mountains, Never Summer Mountains, the Front Range including Rocky Mountain National Park and Indian/James Peaks, Pikes Peak, Sawatch Range and Sangre de Cristo Range.
*WHEN... In effect from 5 PM Wednesday, March 13 until 5 PM Friday, March 15
*IMPACTS... Heavy snow and strong winds have created dangerous avalanche conditions in the backcountry. Large and dangerous avalanches will be very easy to trigger. Avalanches will run naturally.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
